lead_paragraph: By racing dogs in an unmarked field, wealthy Sikh landowners — some of them gas station moguls in the United States — are trying to keep alive the ways of the maharajahs.

headline.print_headline: Chasing the Allure of a Royal Past in Northern India
headline.main: Chasing the Lure of a Royal Past With Greyhound Racing in Punjab

snippet: By racing dogs in an unmarked field, wealthy Sikh landowners — some of them gas station moguls in the United States — are trying to keep alive the ways of the maharajahs.
abstract: Faridkot Journal; wealthy Sikh landowners in town of Faridkot in Punjab, India, are carrying on tradition of dog racing, despite government's attempts to dismantle feudal system in which sport originated; dog races have changed in significant ways since feudal days, but wealthy families cling to tradition that offers them relief from life's toils.
